address: 5 Coronation Rd #01-05 Coronation Arcade Singapore 269406 Singapore
comment: I've been coming to Penang Kitchen since 7 years ago, when I was still a JC kid. It has many memories of my JC times and I absolutely enjoy the food here.The Char Kueh Teow (extra spicy) is a challenge for your taste buds, but is so fragrant you just cant help wanting more. The hokkien mee (or prawn noodle soup as more commonly known in Singapore) has a thick and flavorful broth. I love the lor bak and the balachan chicken.The wait for the food is usually longer since the restaurant is pretty small and they serve everything "home cooked" style.They used to have a student lunch promo but I'm not sure if it is still running! It can get a tad pricey without the promo though!

address: 5 Coronation Rd #01-05 Coronation Arcade Singapore 269406 Singapore
comment: Whenever I have a craving for Assam Laksa, I go here. It's yummm. Their prawn mee is not the best, but they serve very good char kway teow, ngoh hiang (called loh bak) and chicken wings. Warm family atmosphere. Reasonable prices. Hope they continue to stay in business, as the number of outlets serving Assam laksa in central Singapore is dwindling fast.

address: 5 Coronation Rd #01-05 Coronation Arcade Singapore 269406 Singapore
comment: This place is pretty old. It's been here since the 90s. The food is somewhat mixed with some dishes much better than others. Best is the duck soup. It's really rich and flavourful with a sweet herbal taste. There's quite a lot of duck meat inside too and the portion is generous - the portion for 1-2 can feed 2-3.The egg foo Yong is good too. It is an Omelette with lots of ingredients and is tasty and fluffy. The char Kway teow smelled really fragrant but the taste was only so so and didn't have a rich smoky wok taste. The laksa was ok but too spicy. The stock was decently rich.The lor bak was tasty, crispy and juicy but the spice mix reminds me of the Singapore version.The belachan chicken wings were not bad too - well seasoned and crispy.The drinks were most normal but nutmeg lime was interesting. It's the first time I've seen this drink. The nutmeg was judiciously applied and wasn't too strong, adding a pleasant twist to the lime.The Red ruby was pretty good with a reasonable amount of red ruby and clear jelly.What the menu called Gula melaka was really gula melaka sago. And it was great. The gula melaka was very rich and the coconut milk in it complemented it well.Most of the main dishes are a little small for the price though

address: 5 Coronation Rd #01-05 Coronation Arcade Singapore 269406 Singapore
comment: This was for the only place to go to for any kind of Penang food. I know, "but Joe, there are tons of joints serving Penang food," you'll say.  But you'd be wrong.  It's not Penang food that most of those other places serve.  So, let's just let that one go, ok?I used to frequent this place before I discovered Penang Place.  The food here is nostalgically authentic and on the menu, the char kway teow and Penang Rojak deserve  special mention. The char kway teow has enough heat, the noodles are consistently cooked through and al dente, the sprouts are crunchy and the ingredients are fresh but not as fresh or as plentiful as at Penang Place.   They also use a narrower more springy flat rice noodle.  Details, details....The Penang Rojak has fresh ingredients, an authentic base of pungent shrimppaste and a good quality chili paste which is likely homemade.  The water apples (jambu), kelongdong, and jicama chunks are dressed nicely by the rojak sauce and each holds its own in this crunchy, spicy jam session in your mouth.I didn't come here more often, because for Penang food, this place's prices gave me a nosebleed each and every time.  I'm not complaining, nobody put a gun to my head, marched me in, sit and order.  It's just that for what is essentially hawker fare at a mom and pop hole in the wall the prices are steep.  Again, just for the record, not complaining...just saying.

address: 5 Coronation Rd #01-05 Coronation Arcade Singapore 269406 Singapore
comment: I like the fact that the food which Penang Kitchen serves are unpretentious and full of home-cooked flavours. I especially like the lor bak- the meat is crisp on biting but at the same time still tender and melt-in-your-mouth good, and is paired with a special kind of sauce (sweet/chilli). Even though I've never tried their laksa, I've heard from friends that the laksa is also very well done and their generosity with the ingredients more than make up for the small portion. Their ngoh hiang is however rather mediocre with a pasty aftertaste. I've definitely tasted better.They are almost always full during lunch hour and dinner time, even though the turnover rate is pretty fast if you dont mind the wait. Sometimes, the food can take quite long to arrive because alot of orders that come in to the restaurant are not for dine-in customers. Overall, not a bad place to visit, but can be quite a pricey experience if you are looking to try a variety of dishes.

address: 5 Coronation Rd #01-05 Coronation Arcade Singapore 269406 Singapore
comment: This place serves great Penang food and it's my favourite place in Singapore to get Penang hawker fare.  I especially like their Assam Laksa and Penang Char Kway Teow.  Too bad that the Char Kway Teow doesn't come with cockle else it would have been a killer dish.

address: 5 Coronation Rd #01-05 Coronation Arcade Singapore 269406 Singapore
comment: Went there two times. Food is quite tasty but much too expensive. 8,30 for a Char Kway Teow? Seriously? You will find Hawkers who serve you Penang dishes just as good if not better for at least half the price. The extra service and the AC is not worth paying 50% more. Especially when the AC is mot working like when I was there. Will not come back unless they drop the prices.

Everyone was telling me to go to this small breakfast/lunch spot as it is known for its amazing food. I went there for breakfast and it certainly didn't disappoint. It was pretty busy and after I ordered it was hard to find a table (but luckily one opened up!). Due to the corona virus some places were blocked for people to sit on, they also changed their utensils and plates to throw away ones as it would be more hygienic. They did choose utensils that were sourced sustainably which I thought was nice as they did not forget about the environment. The service was good and the food was just amazing. Would recommend the pink lemonade for a nice refresher. I am excited to go back!
Rude cashier with a snotty attitude.They are a small outlet and are disorganized.Not worth the hype.

Microbakery is a great place for breakfast or lunch. You need to order at the counter, the coffees and food will be brought to your table. We ordered the cheese melt and scrambled eggs.Both were very good. They make their own bread, and it is great. I loved the cheese melt. Lots of cheese and qaulity bread. We can also recommend the pink lemongrass lemonade. Although I think they should serve in a larger cup.Friendly service and a real relaxed atmosphere.We can highly recommend. Usually busy, line starts forming before opening at 8:30am, but service is quick.

Chocolate zucchini bread ($5) - 2 starsToo dry!Country bread ($9) - 4.5 starsReally good - chewy on the inside with good sourdough flavour.They kindly sliced the bread and we paid $2 for jam and butter to go with it.Soy cappuccino ($5 + soy) - 4 starsOkay, pretty standard.

If you want a fun option while spending the day at the Botanic Gardens, consider getting the Picnic Buzz-kets from the Bee's Knees @ The Garage. These kits come with two picnic blankets, 3 pillows, two lamps all on a roller wagon to make it easy to enjoy a picnic in the garden.  There are many food options to go along with the kit and we decided to go with the pizza (excellent!), chicken sandwich (great!) with sides of fries. The friendly staff made getting the 'Buzz-kets' easy and had everything prepared for our arrival. We found a shaded spot close by and enjoyed our meal and were in no rush come back.  It was any easy drop off once we were done.

Chose this place coz they open earlier than Halia after our morning walk at Botanical Garden. Had big breakfast, Almond Croissant and Orange Mocha. 1) Big breakfast is so-so. Sourdough is okay, well this meal is just okay. 2) Almond croissant is nice and decent.3) Orange mocha is interesting taste and sweet.

Sweaty and thirsty after walking around at high noon in the gardens?This place is a welcoming spot in spite of the crowds. And of course, there will be crowds as the gardens attract hundreds of tourists each day. This tastefully designed cafe evokes casual brunch fare, sandwiches and salads. I just had lunch so I stopped by for a cocktail and cake, because , why the hell not! The namesake Bee's Knees cocktail (S$18) packs a sting ;) despite the addition of honey in there. Made with sapphire gin and lime, it was a delightful cocktail to cool me down. The coconut shortcake (S$7) that came with my order bordered on the very sweet side, so I only had a few bites. Wander off and be sure to check out the Stingless Bee houses at the Ethnobotany garden. Enjoy and BEE happy!

It's a great location to stop while you're exploring the gardens to refresh. The food was good as was the service. I thought the prices were a tad high, but not overly so. There is an indoor section with air conditioning if you get over heated while walking around.
The food honestly doesn't look that great but the service, drink, and boomin AC are worth the trip after walking through the garden.   I can't speak highly enough about the service, they're so nice.

Good atmosphere, and has a great location, right in the beautiful Botanic Gardens. Nice music taste, and the service is polite and quick. The coffee is very strong, and the cups were a bit small, and the strength gave the coffee a rather bitter taste, but the root beer float was a good size, and had a lovely taste with a scoop of ice cream. Not too crowded, and not too much hustle and bustle. The place bakes it's own bread, and cooks pretty good meals right from it's own kitchen. If the coffee was more refined, this could be a gem within a large rainforest. I would recommend this for a quick snack and drink.
Nice ambience with reasonable tasting food and price. I feel. It would be a great place for weekend brunches

Fresh fruit salad with buttermilk and cinnamon crumble ($9) - 3 starsSmall portion.Ambience - 4 starsI liked that it wasn't too crowded or noisy on a weekday morning. Wifi available but it wasn't working that day.Croissants were $7 each, which is pricey!

I've been eating at Pita Pit over the past 5 months. I eat there at least once a month. It's located right next to the escalator of Galaxis. There's never a crowd there which is good, in the sense that you get your food almost immediately.Pita Pit is a healthy food option, whereby you pick a wrap, either wholemeal or white, and pick a sauce, hummus is my favourite and then pick your vegetables. You can choose to have all your vegetables in the wrap. Then pick a meat, I usually go for the classic caesar chicken. They also give you the option of putting fruits into the wrap.After you have picked all the ingredients that go into wrap. They will place the wrap into a panini press to cook it. All in all, I love that nothing is really oily or fried, and that it's pretty much a giant salad in a wrap. Starts at just $6.90 for a small wrap (6 inches)

Average middle eastern food.Typical unfriendly and unhelpful staff, the kind that you usually find in most restaurants in Singapore. Keeping a tab on the number of squeezes of sauces that they add to your wrap.

address: 73A Ayer Rajah Crescent 0#1-04 Timbre+ Singapore 139957 Singapore
comment: The stall was in a food trunk, located next to the bottle shop. One had to step up to place order. Credit card was accepted. A pager was given which would light up when food is ready.Coconut Cream Prawn Croquette Sandwich with Laksa Cheese (S$10)Thick and juicy inside, crispy on the outside. Looking at a large croquette filled with prawns, chopped onions and coconut milk fried until golden brown at 160 degrees celsius by the hands of Wing. Drenched generously in Gwern's Laksa Cheese and packed in between Wing's homemade buttery brioche.Exclusive Chef Collaboration between Chef Wing Lam of @TheWorldIs.Flat and Chef Gwern Khoi of A Noodle Story for 2nd Timbre+ Open Stoves.Pieces of whole shrimp inside the patty. It was messy eating it as the bun was quite oily and buttery. One wished that the laksa flavour could be stronger.

address: 1J Cluny Road Singapore Botanic Gardens Singapore 259569 Singapore
comment: ample parking.well ventilated and clean.my teh c kosong was not strong enough.the indian stall here is the most popular of the lot.with their prata being the order of the day.i was happy to see two blur guys here.no need to trundle down to tanjong pagar to try them.but i'm concerned about their price point, $12.50 for their prime beef, gruyere and truffle mayo blurger(not a typo).for a food court, i think it is expensive.the quality of beef however can definitely be tasted and it was cooked juicily to specification.the bun also held it's form well.the gruyere cheese was rather mild.the truffle mayo not noticeable.here fries comes with the blurger and a side salad, all on a chopping board.opens daily 7am-9pm.
